movie_review_blurb: Drowned by its gibberish mythology, Warcraft survives because of Duncan Jones' directorial flair, resplendent visuals, and surprisingly deep characterisation. Still feels 10 years too late, though.

For its opening half, Popstar is the funniest film of the year. And even though it tails off, it's still warm, fun, and full of catchy, hilarious songs.
Apocalypse includes everything you'd want in an X-Men movie, including two of the best superhero set pieces ever. But after Days Of Future Past, it feels a tad underwhelming.
Always pleasant, occasionally funny, surprisingly touching, and yet another reason to worship Tom Hanks.

Elvis & Nixon is a consistently funny look at how celebrity and politics merge.

Katie Holmes' impressive directorial debut is peppered with fine performances and stretches what could easily be run-of-the-mill drudgery into a touching, albeit inconsistent, portrayal of modern working class America.

A potent thriller/horror hybrid and further proof of Jeremy Saulnier's directing prowess, even if its ending can't quite match the preceding excellence.
Even though it touches upon topical issues, its drama is forced and hinders rather than compliments proceedings.
Undoubtedly gorgeous to look at. It's just a shame that it doesn't do nearly enough to hook, before laboriously meandering to its foreseeable conclusion.
More hit than miss, Rio, I Love You possesses some vivid and unique vignettes, but it's still basically an elongated tourism advert.
movie_title: Rio, I Love You (Rio, Eu Te Amo) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A tour-de-force of visceral imagery and subtext, High-Rise is pulverizing, powerful, and brazenly idiosyncratic, in a style that's gloriously rare, especially for modern cinema.
Wickedly original, The Neon Demon finds Nicolas Winding Refn at his divisive and provocative best, as he toys, disturbs and, even, infuriates his audience, all with a knowing wink.
Captain Fantastic touches upon thought-provoking themes in an entertaining, touching and funny fashion, while it's effortlessly elevated by a captivating Viggo Mortensen.
Because of the prescience and weight of its plot, Election Year has more legs than its earlier installments, even though it sags in the middle.
God's Not Dead 2 isn't interested in a balanced discussion, and instead plays out in a tedious, cheesy, and frankly infuriating manner.
While Office Christmas Party doesn't possess the requisite amount of belly laughs to become a festive comedy staple its stellar cast still pack in enough chortles to make it enjoyable.
While the gorgeous and mesmerizingly subversive biopic itself is destined to be cult rather than classic, Portman's is a performance for the ages, and one that makes Jackie utterly irresistible.
There's just enough romance, whimsy, creativity and eye-catching visuals to enchant in Fantastic Beasts And Where To Find Them, but its flaws ultimately come close to ruining it all.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [Howard and Hanks] focused on trying to keep the three-quel as simple but still pacey and surprising as possible. But in doing that, they cut corners everywhere.
There's too much talent involved in Keeping Up With The Joneses for it not to be considered a disappointment.
American Honey's brazen modern take on sex, adolescence, and the American dream gone wrong is a challenge, but one that's ever so rewarding.
Awful. Just awful. And while watching it, you get the distinct feeling that everyone involved with When The Bough Breaks knows it, too.
Boasting top-notch performances from its fine ensemble, Morgan is ultimately a satisfying sci-fi thriller, even though, at times, its noticeable, melodramatic kinks threaten to ruin your enjoyment.
Not even Jerry Lewis' first starring role in 21 years can save the languid, lifeless, albeit kind-spirited Max Rose from being a tepid failure.
Edgar Ramirez's terrific leading performance and some astounding boxing sequences make it doubly frustrating that Hands Of Stone never comes to grips with what to do in between bouts.

A top-notch thriller that's also evocative, suspenseful, and increasingly captivating. A must-watch.
The funny, touching, and even a little bit profound biopic of the world's worst ever opera singer, and the ultimate evidence of the power of Streep.
Consistently hilarious, even borderline genius, and the most fun you'll have in a cinema this year.
A delight for children and adults alike until it sadly spirals out of control in its overly ambitious finale.
Slow but effective, Equity thrives because of its all female cast but isn't defined by them, providing a frank, detailed but still imperfect look at modern Wall Street.
An enjoyable but flawed lark.
Despite some impressive set pieces, it ultimately loses steam as it twists to its underwhelming conclusion.
Drenched in cliché and threatens to be completely drab until it's saved by its frightening finale.
It builds well, ultimately gets the best out of its cast, and delivers enough laughs to be more than worthwhile, if just a little bit forgettable.

movie_review_blurb: The Duel boasts an impressively psychotic Woody Harrelson performance, bloody violence, and an intriguing allegorical plot, but it's just all a bit lightweight.

One of the year's best and most psychologically disturbing horror films.
Quaint, breezy and inoffensive... as well as entirely forgettable.

movie_review_blurb: It's the ultimate proof of why we need to see more transgender actresses telling transgender stories, as Vega adds a beauty, poetry, and brutal realism that immediately forges a bond between the character, her story, and the audience.

movie_review_blurb: As it turns out, it's the first, not the last, word of the title that's key to this droll, elegant but faintly trying study in emotional artifice.

Spike Lee convincingly makes the case for reassessment with this exhaustive and entertaining if less-than-penetrating docu on [Bad's] creation.
Worlds don't so much collide as politely bump into each other in [this] glossy, well-meaning but dramatically listless study of class relations in contemporary Paris.
Attractively fizzy pic may be a shock to the system for fans of teen queens Selena Gomez and Vanessa Hudgens, but remains pretty toothless titillation by its writer-helmer's standards.
Andrew Stern's overworked but oddly nonspecific script needs to be a lot savvier about contempo media culture to bear the didactic weight of its themes.
Mehta fudges the political allegory in favour of the story's magical realism, but still can't get her arms around the material - or past Rushdie's own bear-hug.
The intervention of Tony Soprano, who lives not far away, is urgently called for.
Cyrus seems to be playing dress-up when she dons the biker gear that is supposedly her second skin. Not-especially-high high jinks ensue.
A low-fi indie that swiftly slums into terminal feyness.
Newell and Nicholls' safe, schoolteacher-friendly interpretation makes no real case for going down this much-travelled road once more.
A riotous showdown ... finds an absurdly ingenious way both to preserve and subvert the contentiously passive climax of Meyer's novel.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: El Hosaini's voice remains crisp, cool and consistently street-smart.
This is that rare thing: a franchise that grows more winning with each instalment.
Amounts to a lavishly mounted series of airborne sword fights - each one more spectacular (and silly) than the last ...
movie_title: The Flying Swords of Dragon Gate (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Substituting the usual Bollywood song-and-dance with pumped-up bullet ballet, this lengthy but propulsive pic puts a contempo political spin on a classic police-meller formula.
The Knot finds a bumbling groomsman fishing for silver wedding bands in a diarrhea-filled toilet bowl. Viewers searching for moments of wit or insight ... might relate.
Watson holds her own with a character more annoying on paper than in reality, but it's the boys who most impress ...
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: [Spikes] the Nicholas Sparks-style teen Love Story plot with refreshing flashes of sex, drugs and Ellie Goulding songs.
This likable trash occasionally outsmarts more moneyed Hollywood fish features.
Tobias Lindholm's superb [film] actually grows more chillingly subdued as its nightmare scenario unfolds.
Typically arresting direction and a stoically moving lead turn from local industry legend Nora Aunor.
The latest in a long run of 2012 films to confront the indignities of ageing, this one is arguably, if not intentionally, the most harrowing.
A delicately detailed immersion into the world of Z-grade Italian horror cinema that ultimately may or may not be a horror film itself ... a tense, teasing triumph.
[A] mostly sweet-natured rehash of 'Sister Act 2' by way of 'Glee'...
Shepard's crusty charisma gives this dignified genre effort its pulse: a growl-off between his Butch and Jeff Bridges's Rooster Cogburn is surely the next chapter.
It all boils down to a series of riotously extended showdowns between Cavill and Weaver...
[A] lithe, literate, extravagantly daffy redesign of Snow White.
The ensuing good-natured idiocy is tempered with wit and self-awareness: the prospect of further additions to this franchise no longer sounds like divine punishment.
It's a brave irony that a film besotted with the pages of Proust is built around a character who couldn't be more of a closed book.
Though an enthusiastic cast and a somewhat tacked-on feminist twist reduce the sour aftertaste, the tone isn't aggressive or witty enough to distinguish this from umpteen other Guy Ritchie knockoffs.
Donnelly, better known for his work in the music industry, ensures there's enough juddering dubstep on the soundtrack to drown out his pedestrian dialogue.
[A] generous, absorbing, family-authorized docu on the late, still-reigning king of reggae music.
A strained exercise in dramaturgical gimmickry that would be trying even as fringe theater.
The worlds of international boxing and gang-ruled Jamaican politics are twinned to initially eye-opening but ultimately welterweight effect.
Ingeniously passive-aggressive cinema that places great stock in its own thorniness without ever resorting to idle shock-broking.
D.R. Hood's intriguing, well-acted debut draws shifting lines of conflict ... before losing steam in the third act.
A springy, souped-up entertainment whose ample boy's-own pleasures hew far closer to the original Indiana Jones template...
Hitch's most overtly Hitchcockian silent film ...
movie_title: The Lodger: A Story of the London Fog (1928)

movie_review_blurb: Yorgos Lanthimos' first English-language feature is a wickedly funny, unexpectedly moving satire of couple-fixated society.
Overlong and underwritten even by the standards of summer f/x extravaganzas, this Battleship will nonetheless float with many on the strength of its boyish, eager-to-please razzle-dazzle.
The Havana-set Day of the Flowers aims to dance away its script troubles to the infectious rumba rhythms of its soundtrack.
The stars are endearing enough to keep things tolerable, though you may wonder why even McGregor's Scots brogue sounds artificially sweetened here.
If 'The Death of Mr Lazarescu' and '4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days' represented the breakers of the so-called Romanian New Wave, this thinly competent entry is the backwash.
movie_title: If I Want To Whistle, I Whistle (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Friedkin's direction is rough and ready, but Letts's tangy writing is the star here.
This thoughtful but exceedingly modest miniature will be best nursed within the festival circuit.
As with Shankman's knowingly naff 'Hairspray', the sheer performance gusto on display proves thoroughly winning.
Cue a lot of inscrutable double-crossing, 'Murder She Wrote'-level suspense and endless recitations of Handel's 'Messiah' - well, you have to class things up somehow.
movie_title: Requiem for a Killer (Requiem pour une Tueuse) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This effortfully quirky pic refuses to settle for mere ineptitude, adding casual misogyny and pronounced racism to its rap sheet.
There's an argument to be made that there's a calculated degree of cliché to this sweet, Southern-fried fairytale, that Nichols is paying tribute here to his more mainstream inspirations.
A hearty celebration of hard-earned democracy spiked with just enough of the director's acidly crooked humor to remind us whose house we're in.

Hinky, kinky, defiantly unlovable "Cosmopolis" lands in our laps with bristly self-assurance. "You asked for this," it seems to be saying, one of the few things unspoken amid its torrent of thematically pointed verbiage. "Let's see if you really want it."
It's hard to say what forces are propelling this ecstatic, idiotic, fizzy, frightening provocation, but we're moved by them too.
Bringing a child into the world is no laughing matter, and all involved seem to have done their level best to make things as mirthless as possible.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "Killing Them Softly" pleases as an exercise in both surface style and tangy verbiage, but it's the rare genre entertainment one wishes would think a bit less.

With the level of its visual storytelling and rhetorical content hovering perilously around the daytime-TV level, Cannes selectors clearly had their diplomat hats on when admitting this one into Competition.

It's not his underdeveloped narrative that swells "Laurence Anyways" to such an unwelcome length, but the young director's apparent inability to throw out any one of his exquisite shots. Kill your darlings, Master Dolan, and then hang them on the wall.
John Hillcoat's brisk, bloody and sharply appointed Prohibition thriller "Lawless" is the most immaculately barbered film in recent memory.
At 120 minutes, the director perhaps luxuriates in our discomfort a little too long, but it's still a relief to be on our side of the screen.
A grim horror-comedy that amuses only when it tries to alarm.
This rousing, superbly acted, no-holds-barred melodrama is a mighty feat of physical filmmaking.
Lewin, who has fought his own lifelong polio battle, handles tricky material with a gentle, empathetic touch.
There's something alluringly, disconcertingly off-kilter from the get-go in Ain't Them Bodies Saints.
The film may flaunt its true-story credentials for the sake of lurid immediacy but, like the best of its variety, it has a healthy understanding of its own silliness.
This terrific vehicle for the perfectly mismatched comic stylings of Sandra Bullock and Melissa McCarthy isn't a hilarious girl-power trip. It's simply hilarious.

Aware that a story of such grave human weight and consequence demands to be told exactingly if it is to be told at all, Lafosse's film succeeds most profoundly by refusing to phrase the inevitable question -- how could she? -- as a rhetorical one.

The rare contemporary film about Christian behavior that doesn't go out of its way to announce its secularity, it's equally unpatronizing in its sharp articulation of loneliness in middle age and beyond.
As is implicit in the title, the destructiveness of competition is a rippling concern in Bahrani and co-writer Hallie Elizabeth Newton's unpredictably expansive script.

It's the stuff of Saturday-morning cartoons, but Mangold - who, as in the appalling 'Knight and Day', edits all action sequences on the shaky frappé setting - hasn't the visual pop or lightness of touch to make it bounce.
Edgar's script allows ample room for his young stars to exert their considerable goofball charisma.
Walden's structurally elaborate script can't quite conjure the social and environmental detail necessary to make the belief-defying believable on a dramatic level.
Many will respond to the film as a gut-level human interest piece, but it's as curtailed and nuance-free a character study as it is a political polemic.
It's ultimately the film's avoidance of mystery that proves so effective and unnerving.
This good, middlebrow adaptation ... sacrifices much of the novel's structural intricacy for Masterpiece-style emotional accessibility.
A trifling comedy about writer's block that aims for a blend of Richard Curtis-style cheeriness and arch literary satire, and winds up mostly drawing a blank.
It's a testament to the duo's jazzy comic chemistry that they wring some laughs from this dated, frankly sinister premise.
Its repetitive qualities are beyond reproach.
Its morally ambiguous investigation of extreme left-wing politics is ... light years away from usual multiplex concerns.
Scrappy and kind-hearted, with odd flashes of high camp - even if its universe of patchworked Greek mythological elements still makes little sense.

A bit tarter than its predecessors, but not skimping on their woozy, chatty charm, this perfectly played, gently incisive film is a welcome new chapter in one of cinema's most beguiling ongoing romances.
Individual performances range from striking to self-aware, with interaction often hesitant - a drawback in a story predicated on female unity.
Bonitzer is a lithe, literate writer who has penned screenplays for greats such as Jacques Rivette and André Téchiné but it seems he doesn't save his best ideas for himself.
A basically constructed but rivetingly researched examination of the global fight for affordable antiretroviral therapy against Western pharamaceutical companies.
Sumptuous and self-indulgent, Sorrentino's latest is a Fellini-like feast for the eyes.
Honors its subject's stoic reserve, but allows a strain of warm calico romanticism into her remarkable story.
For sheer transference of experience upon the audience, I can think of no film quite like it.
You needn't disagree with the film's cause to feel oppressed by its propagandistic approach - not to mention Philip Glass's relentlessly mournful score.
movie_title: When the Dragon Swallowed the Sun (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's soap, but finely scented.
For "international", read "packed with wince-worthy ethnic stereotyping" - it's the only way the writers know how to define character in a universe this soulless.
Even the good guys have a vampiric air about them.
Wahlberg gives Washington levity; Washington gives Wahlberg resolve.
Bachelorette is very much its own bitter brew, using the comic framework of a botched, coke-fuelled hen night to examine the stinging self-loathing exposed in three women by another's happiest day.
The Expendables meets The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel isn't an obviously winning formula.
A gently lyrical diversion for Ghibli die-hards ... a gentle snooze for others.
Even if Paradise is lost, this remains the trilogy's best film.
In-the-family documentaries are often more emotionally rewarding for their makers than their viewers.
movie_title: My Father and the Man in Black (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The first genuinely characterful action blockbuster of the summer: both a big, beautifully realised throwback to Hollywood Boy's Own storytelling and an intelligent revision of Old West history.
It's a film in which the mere arrival of birdsong on the soundtrack is as a narrative event but there are rewards for the patient; even those easily bored should leave the cinema feeling soothed.
It's as hard to look away from Shannon's performance as it is to look directly at it.
The pic is ostensibly more conventional than Barnard's acclaimed hybrid-doc debut, The Arbor, but exhibits stunning formal progress nonetheless.
This elegant, geographically vivid pic is considerably leaner than its melodramatic premise might suggest.
It's as distinct from its genre forerunners as Aldi is from Lidl, but German director Philipp Stölzl keeps things moving at a fair clip.
The scenery is suitably magnificent, but this well-meaning film scarcely says enough to fill its 75-minute running time.
Ozon weaves another spellbinding tale that mingles the real and imaginery with terrific effect.
It's a kick to see Boyle back in lickety-split genre mode.
A proficient but personality-free policer that demands little of either its audience or its enviable best-of-British cast.
Rank even on its own terms, it's the kind of inferior remake that also invites questions about the original's cult status.
Scott Graham's haunting, minimalist debut grips from the outset with startling photography and an attention-grabbing turn from newbie actress Chloe Pirrie.
[A] precious, pointless exercise in designer neurosis from mononymic artist-turned-filmmaker Carter.

What it lacks, rather like Oscar himself, is any authentic magic: the script's post-'Shrek' wisecracks feel especially out of place, and the over-processed digital landscapes can't match the beauty of handmade Hollywood artifice.
Disney's found a lot to play with here, but you may find yourself itching to take the controls.
Offers an elegantly muted take on the midlife ennui of Kerouac's autobiographical 1962 novel.
Bullhead more than deserves its run at the big screen. So does its star.
A splendidly demented gumbo of Hitchcock thriller, American Gothic fairy tale and a contemporary kink all Park's own.
Quote not available.
Looks dirtily chic and boasts an unsurprisingly sharp soundtrack, but is on less sure footing with its credibility-straining delineation of a sadomasochistic relationship.

Kosinski continues to lavish far more thought on how his elaborate fantasy worlds look than how they work, and neither the politics nor the human stakes here coalesce into rational or relatable drama.
The thrills and the effects are cheap, but this is in hard-driving, good-humoured command of its own silliness.
Has taken almost two years to reach the UK; you'd be forgiven for thinking it was far longer, given its sub-Joseph Losey pretensions and doily-like styling.
This playful and elegiac documentary is wholly of a piece with Sarah Polley's fiction work, and just as rewarding.
A sly, insidious and intermittently hilarious domestic thriller that is likely to remain one of the most daring selections of this year's Cannes competish.
[Kore-eda's] latest, for all its careful construction and sweet pockets of feeling, is his glibbest and most morally one-sided film to date.
It's travelogue cinema for the dissolute and gravely disenfranchised.
An intimate epic in every sense of the term, its every subtle emotional turn rendered widescreen on [Adèle] Exarchopoulos's exquisitely expressive face.
Heli executes its shocks with sleek, gasp-inducing effectiveness, but neither it politics, nor its shifts in physical perspective, ever surprise or disorientate us.
There's something exhilarating -- mesmerizing, even -- about The Congress's most ludicrous flourishes.
The Past further showcases Farhadi's dexterity as a dramatist of uncommon perspicacity and fairness.
Before you can say it's a dog-eat-dog world out there, Green serves us with a tawdrily obvious scene in which one dog does indeed eat another.
Hot and cold and provocative in more than just the expected ways, Stranger by the Lake presents even the most dishonest sex as an honest thrill.
A wise, wintry ode to artistry lost, found and placed in storage.
As interpretation, it's timid at best, taking the emotional accents of its irony-strewn, often bitterly funny source very much at face value.
As well as a touching and tough-minded love story, Behind the Candelabra is a sympathetic study of a man defiantly resisting his own significance.

The only scenes in which blood isn't virtually seeping from the walls in Nicolas Winding Refn's sleek, stunted, undeniably startling revenge thriller are those in which it's quite literally splashing them.
Payne can't seem to decide if he's coddling these old-school Midwesterners for their rudely rustic values or sneering at the sheer narrowness of their worldview.
Genre buffs will dig in with gusto.
[D]ispassionately subversive and quietly modern, The Bling Ring may well be a morality tale with no moral.
[Desplechin has] come a cropper in this lethargic, self-important psychiatry study, which he himself seems to have directed from the couch.
Felix Thompson's Tribeca-awarded debut covers familiar coming-of-age material with sensitivity and style.
May rep a sincere spillage of its creator's soul, but it's also a work of stony, audience-opposed self-indulgence ... A major disappointment from a major filmmaker."
movie_title: A Lullaby to the Sorrowful Mystery (2016)

movie_review_blurb: From this droll premise, potentially as dark and dry as blackened toast, Hausner spins a witty, unexpectedly touching meditation on the nature of partnership and the elasticity of fate.
Diane Keaton and Brendan Gleeson aren't an obvious match; despite their combined lovability, this slender romcom doesn't prove otherwise.
Even if it never quite takes the risks implied by its exclamatory title ... "Leap!" follows the established steps with general grace and good humor.
Ramsay has made more sensually rapturous films, but this may be her most formally exacting: No shot or cut here is idle or extraneous.

As focus lurches distractingly from the heated dinner-table debate to a zigzagging network of flashbacks, momentum fatally stalls, while the illustrious ensemble of actors at the film's center never quite gets cooking.
As redesigns go, Alien: Covenant is not ambitious, but it's roaringly, repulsively effective.
Merges the Safdies' signature gutter realism with tight genre mechanics to discomfiting but exhilarating effect.
There's a reason why petits fours are a patisserie staple, and grands fours are not: what's puffily perfect at bite size can turn cloying in a larger slice.
Laurent Cantet makes an enthralling return to form with this topical fusion of political debate session and socially conscious thriller.
A gentle-hearted, quintessentially new-age but fatally cloying new outing from Japan's premier cinematic naturalist Naomi Kawase.
Lacking the emotional and structural complexity of some recent Hong outings, it's minor even by his minor-key standards.
Robin Campillo's outstanding AIDS activist drama melds the personal, the political and the erotic to heart-bursting effect.
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A trifle compared to such recent Hong highs as "Right Now, Wrong Then" and "On the Beach at Night Alone," but a complete work on its own light terms.
A big, bleeding feat of extreme cinema, given elevating human dimension by rising star Joe Cole's ferociously physical lead performance.
Gains artful integrity from Zhao's favored docu-fiction technique - roughly tracing a script around the experiences of her non-professional actors - and dusty-dreamy visual style.
"A Ciambra" is something of a step sideways for the Italian-American filmmaker, consolidating his considerable formal and observational gifts while fumbling a bit as storytelling.
Bruce Willis barks up a number of wrong trees in this scattered, only sparsely amusing shaggy-dog mystery.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Venice (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are no stagecoaches or six-shooters in this sharp, simmering drama of German-Bulgarian discord, but the spirit of John Ford graces it.
"Marie Curie: The Courage of Knowledge" doesn't have to clear a very high bar to be more entertaining than it sounds - and so it does, albeit none too smoothly.
movie_title: Marie Curie: The Courage of Knowledge (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A 27-year-old comedian and Daily Show correspondent given ample room to breathe, riff and roar by director Jim Strouse's script, Williams bounds into the proceedings with unfiltered comic peculiarity.
There's a small, or perhaps not so small, part of this beautiful, spectacular attack of a movie that wants to be booed, but that doesn't mean we should be swift to do so.

The vicarious intrigue of watching someone else's increasingly distant drug trips burns out pretty fast, leaving viewers with an abstruse fusion of stoner cinema and slow cinema that plays to no obvious audience.
[An] unsteady, overlong but rewardingly compassionate character study ...
Thanks to cinematographer Mark Lee Ping-bing's indelible image-making, the material gains a tactility distinct from what the written word can achieve.
Fonda and Redford play this potentially sleepy material with spry, generous adroitness, genuinely listening and subtly playing off each other's reactions and body language.

The frustrating nine-year wait for new material from Martel has done nothing to blunt her exquisite, inventive command of sound and image, nor her knack for subtly violent exposure of social and racial prejudice on the upper rungs of the class ladder.

A ravishing, eccentric auteur's imagining, spilling artistry, empathy and sensuality from every open pore, it also offers more straight-up movie for your money than just about any Hollywood studio offering this year.
This well-meaning film winds up seeming more than a little obtuse in its flat avoidance of geopolitical detail, not helped by disproportionately faint sketching of its non-western characters ...
The heart-in-hand sincerity of its worldview is what makes the film endearing and aggravating by turns.
McLean has picked an opportune moment to demonstrate his skills outside the bloodiest horror wheelhouse. Job done.
Bless Al Gore and everything he stands for, but not every picture is worth a thousand words.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Far from a complete painting, this is a sketch, an outline, done in casual, quick strokes and left both intriguingly and frustratingly rough ...
A sweat-slicked, exhausting but glibly entertaining escapade on its own terms, "American Made" is more interesting as a showcase for the dateless elasticity of Cruise's star power.

Shot and styled in contemporary, ticking-clock action fashion, it compresses the complex Theatcher-era politics of its fractious standoff into a simplified West-versus-Middle-East conflict that registers as broadly topical.
A sly, sexy and strangely disarming cruise along the queerer backroads of rural France that marks an intriguing debut for writer-director Jérôme Reybaud.
The spare, humanist influence of Ozu is plain to see here, but Fukada's tone is all his own, simultaneously shot through with violence and compassion.
No film since Fargo has made so much use of [Frances McDormand's] potent talents.

An oddly alluring film that does a double backflip on hokey showbiz-bio convention: not an informative introduction to the singer by any means, but a suitably eccentric evocation of her creative essence.
Six decades into her career, still restless with feeling and fury, Vanessa Redgrave clearly isn't done surprising us.
As cuttingly observed as it is pristinely composed.
Opaque and formally ungainly, this itchy meditation on a host of contemporary social ills offers audiences a vividly, deliberately ugly worldview, but finally makes for hollow viewing.
Unfussy in form, open in expression and gentle in reach as its maker revisits such recurring preoccupations as loneliness, regret and the value of love in life and art.
movie_title: On the Beach at Night Alone (Bamui haebyun-eoseo honja) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Even at their least individually striking, each of these mismatched tasters stirs an appetite for a fuller, meatier meal from its maker - cooked as bloodily rare as possible, please.
A deliciously heightened, caviar-black comedy that sets up its brittle, bourgeois characters like bowling pins and gleefully knocks them down in 71 minutes flat.

"Viceroy's House" clumsily merges a waxworks biographical study of Lord Louis and Lady Edwina Mountbatten ... with a passionless Romeo-and-Juliet romance between two of their servants caught in the fray.
Karukoski's film at least honors its subject's work in some key respects: It's handsome, smoothly executed and eager to entertain.
Gomis' latest ... [weaves] a sensual, sometimes hopeful, sometimes disturbing urban tapestry with threads of image, sound, poetry, and song.
The air trickles out of this sensitive but cliché-laced drama ...
A determinedly eccentric but intermittently startling misfit romance that marks a singular return to feature filmmaking for Hungarian writer-director Ildikó Enyedi after an 18-year gap.
movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Teströl és Lélekröl) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Even its most audacious device - the undifferentiated braiding of pure documentary and narrative footage - feels a tad old hat relative to newer hybrid forms in nonfiction filmmaking.
For all its structural and psychological deficiencies, it's hard not to enjoy "Fifty Shades Darker" on its own lusciously limited terms.
Chon's sophomore feature wavers uncertainly in tone, getting a little too cute for comfort in spots, but is otherwise a lively, auspicious breakthrough.

[It] may not be the most comprehensively explanatory or analytical film yet made on the war, but it's the one that provides viewers with the most sensorily vivid and empathetic sense yet of how it feels to live (and die) through the carnage.
"T2," for all its noise and neon, has little to say to fill it.
An earthy, quietly stirring Spanish fable that finds familial, regional and environmental grievances inseparably tangled in its branches.

Binoche, like her compatriot Isabelle Huppert, is an actress so adept at serenely conducting inner turmoil that we risk taking their range of notes and tones for granted. Even by her standards, however, this is complex, quietly symphonic work ...
movie_title: Let the Sunshine In (Un beau soleil intérieur) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Kirill Serebrennikov's study of a problem teenager's religious awakening is as aesthetically kinetic as it is intellectually rigorous.
Narrative and reality clash, tussle, and are eventually rendered indistinguishable in a witty, tortured puzzle picture ...
It's hard not to be moved by the dedication and affection that the Headfort staff -- given a bit more individual scrutiny here than the children -- put into their work.
There's little to dislike about this second shot of "Whisky," with its appealing ensemble and hat-in-hand approach to the Ealing playbook; there's just equally little reason for it to exist.

Michael Apted's efficient but unstylish film has only a prestigious cast of supporting slummers - Michael Douglas, Toni Collette, John Malkovich - to distinguish it from a "Spooks"-style TV outing.
A sexually frank but narratively flimsy girl-meets-girl romance that never gets under its gorgeous characters' amply exposed skin.
An elegantly lean, low-temperature thriller from Swiss writer-director Frédéric Mermoud.
Werner Herzog's latest half-hearted return to narrative cinema is more excited by its stunning landscape than the life inside it.
Even if it never quite takes the risks implied by its exclamatory title ... "Leap!" follows the established steps with general grace and good humor.
Led by a resolute Scarlett Johansson, Rupert Sanders' pulse-quickening, formally stunning live-action take on the manga classic both honors and streamlines its source.

Extravagantly surreal as the products of his imagination may be, they are deeply rooted in personal history and philosophy -- and it's this connection that Jon Nguyen's disarmingly off-kilter documentary... probes to rewarding effect.
Austin Lynch - son of David - makes a strong impression with this solemnly teasing, semi-documentary mood piece.
[A] living, breathing, stunning documentary study of an African-American family in North Philadelphia weathering a tumultuous decade.

What's most impressive about Murray and Crow's winning performances ... is that they keeping matters suitably upbeat while projecting a hint of the weariness and desperation we can't quite see in the set-dressing.
Goldby's film does ... prove that both Collinses should have been better used over the years, even as it slightly misuses them itself.
Ott has artfully constructed a slippery hall of human mirrors, testing and subverting the rules of empathy in documentary and narrative cinema alike.

Neasa Ní Chianáin's gentle but keen-eyed documentary celebrates contemporary, constructive methods of elementary education, while also taking cozy comfort in the more longstanding aspects of the institution.

I laughed in many of the places where Suburbicon wants us to laugh, yet something feels ill-balanced from the get-go-like a carelessly mixed gin and tonic that you drink anyway, wincing at the bitter follow-through.

Ensemble work is excellent across the board, with those cast as the various evictees contributing a particularly vivid gallery of one-scene performances, ranging in tone from white-hot fury to silent desolation.
Superb, skin-prickling performances by the three principals contribute invaluably to the pic's stern believability.
It's not heavy-imprint filmmaking, but its breezy, benevolent warmth stays with you after its immediate details begin to fade.

A sex-free, PG-13 version of "Freed" could be cut without shedding a second of narrative coherence, such as it is; one could ask what the point of that would be, though similar queries might be leveled at the film as it stands.
"The Mercy" tells its story - once headline material, now poignantly little-remembered - about as well as it can be told.
"Night Comes On" is, true to its title, blanketed in a dim, crepuscular state of waiting. Fishback, her film career unfurling clearly before her from scene to scene, blazes a way out of it.
Lorna Tucker's consistently entertaining, enthralled portrait of aberrant British fashion designer Vivienne Westwood.
[Eklöf] has the provocateur's gift for images that needle, nettle and stick, well before their message locks firmly into place.
Sets up a familiarly dysfunctional family reunion, only to make several surprising switches in tone.
It's a film as compellingly all over the shop as its subject, even if it doesn't quite have her beat on stylistic verve and risk.

"Yardie" has the right look, the right sound and the right moves to play with the bigger boys of its genre; like its young, scrappy but naive hero, however, there's not quite enough power behind its posturing.
Dweck's stoically composed, strangely mesmerizing film makes a strong case for the humble speedway's soul.
If Hofmann doesn't deliver a payoff quite worthy of his premise, "Time Share" remains an arresting, electric tease; edgier arthouse distributors should book themselves in.
As a final, permanent showcase for a role Everett was born to play, then, "The Happy Prince" does the job.
"Rust" isn't empty hand-wringing, but characterized by genuine concern for, and empathy with, the children under its watch.
Moves no needles cinematically or politically, but makes a heartening call for open-armed empathy in an America still guarded on that front.
A riveting college-boy crime caper that tiggers along on pure movie-movie adrenalin, before U-turning into a sobering reflection on young male privilege and entitlement.
Say "Isle of Dogs" fast and it comes out sounding an awful lot like "I Love Dogs" - which makes sense, since that's pretty much the chief takeaway from Wes Anderson's delightful new animated feature.
Its sharpest passages ... exert the bracing, mouth-shuddering tang of neat ouzo: You know how it's going to taste, but it leaves you wincing anyway.
A fine, sensitive leading turn from Emily Mortimer helps shore up these quiet, lightly dust-covered proceedings, but can't quite put "The Bookshop" in the black.
All the narrative's blank spaces, previously well-guarded by editor Julia Gregory, collapse into a fudged finale of stuttering irresolution.
[A] short, riveting exploration of adolescent psychosis, teacherly responsibility, and the moral minefield that connects them.
movie_title: Shock Waves - Diary of My Mind (Journal de ma tête) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: If a few more guys start eating their greens as a result, this blunt but belief-fueled film will have done its job.

At least gives the Commission's heroic chairman, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, his due by placing him front and center in its history - though it's debatable whether Forest Whitaker's glazed impersonation should be considered an honour.
It's as an ambiguous study of parenting a prodigy that the film lingers on the palate, as McGarry's mother Meg documents and manages his evolution to an obsessive, gradually oppressive degree.
"Finding Your Feet" hits its romantic-comedy beats with an old-timer's clockwork efficiency.
Hushed, deliberate and realised with considerable care and beauty, the resulting film has its heart entirely in the right place; its pulse, unfortunately, is far harder to locate.

"Lemonade" remains effective and agitating precisely where it needs to be, while the subtleties of Manovici's performance, clouding her ingenue-like appearance with flashes of hard-lived savvy, keep the drama on edge.
For better or worse, it's the kind of feature one can imagine being presented on one side of a DualDisc album edition, if only Sheeran's primary demographic still consumed physical media.

"Eldorado's" historical narrative is inevitably less vividly portrayed than its contemporary one, though that in itself is poignant: a reminder of how fragile individual migrants' stories are to begin with ...
We're in schlock corridor here and Soderbergh runs with it, cellphone in hand; under the buzzing suspense mechanics, however, a cautionary note on the perils of disbelieving women is just audible.
When you're almost grateful for a late bout of torture porn to break up the tedium, it doesn't say much for the film's ideas, however poetically expressed and visualized they may be.
movie_title: My Brother's Name Is Robert and He Is an Idiot (Mein Bruder heißt Robert und ist ein Idiot) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Diaz remains emphatically his own artist, whether to exhilarating or punishing effect: "Don't give in to the masses' sensibilities!" warns one of his typically catchy lyrics, and you can't say he doesn't practice what he preaches.
movie_title: Season of the Devil (Ang Panahon ng Halimaw) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: An undeniably engrossing but almost entirely specious affair: Any factual grounding gives way beneath the film as it devolves into shrill heart-versus-head melodrama.
"U - July 22" is designed to be as immersive as it is exhausting, and largely succeeds ...
The unwavering human kindness of "The Prayer" - a film as clean and bracing as the mountain air that surrounds it - sees it through to something truthful.

"Transit" invites viewers to trace their own speculative connections between Seghers' narrative and the contemporary rise in neo-Nazism and anti-refugee sentiment, all while its surtext remains achingly moving.
A high-concept, low-budget and skilfully muscle-tensing Danish thriller to which you can imagine more than a couple of eager Tinseltown execs angling for the remake rights.
Hungarian docmaker Bernadett Tuza-Ritter's stirring, Sundance-tapped debut draws a hapless victim of modern-day slavery from the shadows.
Short, sour-sweet and content to leave ideas and characters trailing in the summer breeze, "My Art" has evidently been made strictly on Simmons' terms, however wafty those may be.
If, at over two hours, it is an undeniably onerous watch, that is by design: Finkiel's film certainly understands the taxing nature of sorrow.
Córdova's film brings little that's new to its stylistic school of observational realism - but hits the Caracas sidewalks hard and purposefully enough to compensate.

There's a lot of ravaged ground to cover here, and editor Alyse Ardell Spiegel does well to compress these differing, sometimes opposing, perspectives into an efficient encapsulation that won't bewilder viewers unfamiliar with the Congolese crisis.
Lindsay Burdge's intrepid performance as a woman unable to let go of a one-night stand galvanizes Nathan Silver's sharply stylized character study.
Makes a proud point of its unpleasantness.
What the film occasionally lacks in human finesse, it makes up for in sheer anything-goes resolve.
[A] thoughtful, lyrical, slightly over-deliberate tour of a beautiful teenage wasteland.
Keeps its eyes moist and its upper lip stiff to the last - but its sweeping inspirational gestures rarely reach all the way to the heart.

There's scarcely room here for improvement at the level of craft or performance; in particular, it's gratifying to see leading lady Ruth Wilson headlining a big-screen vehicle worthy of her flinty brilliance.
Gemma Arterton's strong but shattered performance as a disconnected housewife bolsters Dominic Savage's thoughtful marital drama.

Upgrading a sleeping-with-the-enemy premise familiar from countless B-thrillers with a faintly mythic aura and cool psychosexual shading, "Beast" also sustains a fresh, frank feminine perspective through Jessie Buckley's remarkable lead performance.
This is an impressively rigorous exercise, in which the director's sober formalism finds a kindred spirit in his leading lady's studied, secretive restraint.

The spare, classical chase drama that ensues is seeded with barbed observations on colonialism, cultural erasure and rough justice, kept poetically succinct by Thornton's lithe, soaring visual storytelling.

It's as a modest but dedicated showcase for [Mora] Arenillas, her face alive with fear, exasperation and questioning even when her character feels most depleted, that "Invisible" sticks most stubbornly in the mind.
Long, loud and lurid, with a distinct whiff of week-old quesito colombiano.
The engrossing result feels entirely modern, despite more spectacular, candy-colored ruffles than you can shake a bustle at.
Pin Cushion is most emotionally piercing in depicting the daily ways in which the world still punishes this loving, mild-as-milk woman for her difference.
Antoniak's spare script doesn't probe too deeply into his ruptured psyche, meaning much of "Beyond Words" falls in a curious tonal middle ground between earnest and ersatz.
[Ahmad] most formally stylized and refined effort to date, Decor proves his elasticity of technique and emotional empathy,
All the Money in the World is too stolid and sluggish to distract us from its own behind-the-scenes drama.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Styler's peppy but thin foray into feature direction is especially disappointing following her strong track record as a producer of more singular, stylistically confident indies ...

There's a regal, rolling sense of great-outdoors scale to "Hunting Season," a confident, clean-lined debut from Argentinian writer-director Natalia Garagiola, that only puts the internal shuttering of its young protagonist in starker relief.

Collet-Serra cranks up this locomotive as he knows best, building as much breathless, senseless real-time momentum as possible before train and plot go simultaneously, albeit spectacularly, off the rails.
An intricately crafted, infinitely wrongfooting psychological thriller in which conflicting realities coalesce, diverge and regroup like so many shifting formations of jewel-colored glass.
An intrepid, cold sweat-inducing study of Jihadi radicalization in the home from celebrated Syrian docmaker Talal Derki.
Just watching it induces veritable stomach cramps, though it's impossible to turn away from the film's whipcrack construction and expert manipulation of perspective.

"Winnie" gradually reveals itself to be rather a specious work, unabashedly one-sided in its adherence to the "mother of the nation" line pushed by her admirers, and its factually selective absolution of Madikizela-Mandela ...
There's a unifying purpose to this seemingly scattered approach, underlining the essential unknowability of a retiring figure who left principally his art as evidence of a jagged, unstable life.
Settles on viewers as quietly as overnight snow on a wintering field.

Another near-pawfect family entertainment, honoring the cozy, can-do spirit of Bond's stories while bringing them smoothly into a bustling, diverse 21st-century London - with space for some light anti-Brexit subtext to boot.
All are lovingly caught in Raúl Pérez Ureta's unassuming camera lens, though that love is spiked with the filmmakers' own sense of sorrow for the past and concern for the future.
movie_title: Last Days in Havana (Últimos días en La Habana) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A production that seems to have been second-, third- and fourth-guessed at every turn, and bears the manifold scars and stitches of on-the-fly rethinking.
Chilean director Sebastián Lelio and star Daniela Vega give the growing bracket of transgender drama a new, luminous touchstone work.
"Apostasy" is rare in its visceral and philosophical intensity.
A loosely woven brain-teaser with a creepingly intense emotional undertow, this marks a confident, collected first foray into features directing for Taiwanese commercials veteran Lai Kuo-An.
movie_title: A Fish Out of Water (Shang an de yu) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A thin, sparkless romantic comedy that takes satirical aim at a host of current hipster-culture targets ...
A bit of a trudge, despite Dinklage's committed and empathetic performance.
Goes soft and strangely condescending on us, coming within perilous distance of white-savior tradition as Damon becomes the change he'd like to see in the new world.
A soul-searing Michelle Pfeiffer makes a welcome return in Andrew Dosunmu's difficult, visually stunning essay in psychic pain.
An unimaginable reality is brought to the brink of clarity -- only to plunge right back into a psychological abyss -- in Danish helmer Jeppe Ronde's potent, pain-ridden Bridgend.

Slickly upbeat as it guides six contrasting clients through the measuring and fitting process, frosh helmer Benjamin's film nonetheless gleans enough pointed personal testimonies along the way to add human weight to its makeover-TV format.

This bouncily entertaining doc may boast only a notch more formal ambition than a very well-assembled "Behind the Music" special, but is no less essential than Lee's first MJ opus, the excellent "Bad 25."
movie_title: Michael Jackson's Journey From Motown to Off the Wall (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Even as its tone circles back to aching naturalism, there's something tenuous about the pic's tender resolution -- not to mention a teasing sense that more interesting untold stories might lie on the untold fringes.
Nicolas Pesce's impressive, highly original horror fable is the stuff of very beautiful nightmares.
Robert Greene's performance-based documentary on Christine Chubbuck is an ingenious, knowingly frustrating provocation.
For a documentary on his work to clock in at just 72 minutes doesn't seem fitting in any sense.
Meera Menon's soph feature puts a welcome feminine spin on the financial-crisis drama.
If it all finally amounts to a slightly academic anatomy of an idea, it's a killer idea all the same.
The emotional responses elicited here go about as deep as the "awwws" and "ahhhs" of a live studio audience at a network sitcom taping.
Lightning strikes thrice as Irish writer-director John Carney's let's-make-a-band formula once more yields winning results.
Kelly Reichardt's wonderful triptych of female character studies confirms her status as the quietest of great American filmmakers.
Brian Oakes' family-endorsed study of the slain U.S. photojournalist movingly humanizes the victim of an unspeakable tragedy.
Rebecca Hall aces the role of her career in Antonio Campos' impeccably observed account of the Christine Chubbuck tragedy.
A hapless Dachshund witnesses the spectrum of human unhappiness in this sly, stimulating provocation from Todd Solondz.
Mia Hansen-Love and Isabelle Huppert prove a dream partnership in the director's gorgeous, heart-cradling post-divorce drama.
Maggie Greenwald's first adult-oriented feature since 'Songcatcher' is an affecting, rose-scented study of small-town prejudice and female friendship.
Oliver Schmitz, one of South Africa's essential directors, delivers a mix of emotional acuity and overkill with this death penalty drama.
What sets the film drastically off-balance is its contrastingly finicky impulse to paint Dickinson as one of the rapier wits of her generation.
To what degree these narratives highlight universalities or distinct, disparate facets of love is in the eye of the beholder; either way, Har'el saturated sensory technique is a seduction in itself.
[The Chosen Ones,] while a little one-note in its dramatic development, is as hard to shake as it is to watch.
An audience picture first and foremost: one wholly sympathetic to its eponymous subject's delusional drive to delight crowds with or without the requisite artistry.

As delicately drawn by Daly and co-writer Glenn Montgomery, the nervous, mutually tip-toed bond that reveals itself between Margaret and Joe runs counter to the luridly melodramatic lines threatened by the premise.

With its heavy image processing and injudicious use of slo-mo, there's a certain student-film quality to The Adderall Diaries that neither masters nor disciplines the complex, eccentric sprawl of the source material.
Doubled-up diva-tude, however, can't ignite a rhythmically flat, seemingly committee-helmed franchise outing that never decides on its dramatic center.
It's an expertly executed tease.
A familiarly premised but stringently executed home-invasion chiller that rarely goes for the straight-up scare when a more insidious one will do.

Cruddily crafted, grimacingly performed and effortlessly racist, this sloppy dish of Gruel Britannia may just go down well enough to green-light a continuing franchise of global destruction. World capitals quiver.

[Sivas] is distinguished by its muscular technical brio and rich, integral sense of place. As storytelling, however, it's less rewarding, taking rather too long to get into gear and abruptly ending at its most critical point of conflict.
There are gentle rewards to be gained from the initially brittle, gradually tender rapport between two actors of contrasting greatness.
Alike in formal spryness if nothing else, the five form one of the category's most sophisticated lineups in recent memory.
Aims for a bittersweet release of feeling that lands, at its most misjudged points, closer to emotional sadism.
A fine-cut tension exercise that eventually ignites into a full-blown home-invasion thriller.
Finally cushions its harshest emotional blows, though Brendan Gleeson's deeply sad, stoic dignity in the lead cuts through some of the padding.
A sensitive, slow-developing bruise of a film.
The trailblazing TV showrunner gets a lively tribute in Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady's technically imaginative doc.
movie_title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's heartening to see energetic supporting players accommodated so generously in a vehicle otherwise decisively steered by its two smashing leads, whose ping-ponging chemistry doesn't drop for a minute.
The amiably ambling result is unlikely to shift the divide between Hong's enchanted admirers and impatient skeptics.
Boys will be boys, yes, but Cividino doesn't romanticize them: They can be pretty toxic, too.
The emotional conclusions here can be a little pat, and catharsis too easily come by. It's more cautiously sound-proofed than its title implies.

This exhilarating tale of a winsome Spanish nightclubber who finds herself spontaneously caught up in a bank robbery... is undeniably a stunt, but one suffused with a surprising degree of grace and emotional authenticity.
Rare is the prestige biopic that feels altogether too short, but after 102 soundly paced minutes, "The Program" retires with half a hill left to climb.
A grandly ornery Maggie Smith is the chief draw in this slight, innocuously enjoyable adaptation of Alan Bennett's memoir.
Despite Christopher Plummer's poignant lead performance, Atom Egoyan fails to find form in this Nazi-tracking mystery.
Steered by Noah Baumbach and Jake Paltrow, Brian De Palma holds court in a delightful, illuminating career reflection.
Hardy's astonishing, award-caliber twin turn as the notorious Kray brothers deepens and darkens Brian Helgeland's biopic.
A sequel may be far from a guaranteed prospect, but the pic does establish the elastic-faced Whitehall as a film-anchoring comic presence (and writer) for other, similarly lightweight vehicles.
Baumbach times his choreographed comic collisions with the snap and crackle of vintage Hollywood farce, with Gerwig as the gloriously humanising centre of the chaos ...
As a late-summer aperitif - suavely assembled, chilled and tinted by the sunset - this jaunty nonsense slips down smoothly enough.
Accumulates the necessary narrative chaos without ever building a full head of comic steam.
[An] unexpected, unpredictable and profoundly unnerving psychological thriller ...

Inventively visualised and electrified by Powley's vibrant star turn, this is mature, spirited, emotionally generous filmmaking that understands under-18s far better than innumerable insipid young adult romances.
movie_title: The Diary Of A Teenage Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Palka's fourth feature is as brash and as blunt as its title, more abrasive than amusing in its snarling takedown of patriarchal family politics.
Tone-deaf and structurally haphazard.
This allegedly fact-based tale of Satanic suspicions in small-town Minnesota is potboiler material at best, threatening far twistier terrors than those it predictably delivers.
It takes all the leads' considerable combined charm to forestall the aftertaste of the pic's smug life lessons and near-comically blinkered worldview.
A gleefully grisly genre gazpacho that matches a rousing sense of Old West derring-do to a comic sensibility as dark as chewing tobacco - and at least as much of an acquired taste.
Those who stick out its short-and-sour duration, however, will note a deepening timbre in Silver's already distinctive storytelling voice, as he deftly balances curdled comedy with candid humanism.

Fevered imagination and nightmarish reality brush shoulders to disconcerting effect in The Demons, Quebecois filmmaker Philippe Lesage's extraordinary examination of childhood fears festering in broad suburban daylight.

The quasi-Kafkaesque administration holding Zimbabwean president Robert Mugabe's corrupt dictatorship in place finally gets the first-hand scrutiny it merits in Camilla Nielsson's riveting documentary Democrats.
It's the satisfying feature-length overview that Joplin's brief, fiercely brilliant career has long merited.
The powerful and precarious position of photojournalists in modern-day Afghanistan is the subject of this sharp, soulful doc.
The film retains its own distinctive storytelling sensibility.
The tone is light and hopeful throughout, while allowing for the possibility of more searching investigation on the viewer's part.
It's Watkins' lean, keen instinct for choreographing and cutting action set pieces that keeps "Bastille Day" afloat.
Grabby and grubby in equal measure, this meticulously composed trawl through the contents of several middle-class Austrians' cellars yields more than a few startling discoveries.
[The film] has been entered for the Best Foreign Language Film Oscar - good luck to them, but British cinema has been better represented. So, for that matter, has Dylan Thomas.
Russell Crowe heads a starry, largely overqualified cast in Gabriele Muccino's treacly, time-hopping family soap opera.

A wealth of iconography - both incidental and integral - from the series' founding chapters is revived here, making "Spectre" a particular treat for 007 nerds, and a businesslike blast for everyone else.

Too drab to succeed even as defiantly unvirtuous trash ... stifles Diesel's rough-hewn charisma via a sludgy, impermeable oil spill of CGI effects - in the service of largely unspectacular hocus pocus.

This low-key but deeply felt tale of fraternal bonds... reps a confident feature-length debut for the Texas-born Kim, who brings both non-native objectivity and a traveler's eye for geographic detail to the pic's earthy Bangkok setting.
movie_title: How to Win at Checkers (Every Time) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Brashly uneven and wildly overlong, this comedy of brotherly love and outsider acceptance nonetheless boasts a spirited, audience-pleasing core.
The part-toon pic's neatly collapsing structure and pop-art flourishes ensure it's never dull.
The remarkable career of Senegalese filmmaker Sembene Ousmane gets an appropriate overview in this intelligent, slightly dry doc.
It's the high-gloss realization of that world that affords many of the pic's most delicious pleasures.
A smutty but strained spy spoof in which most of the human-based comedy stays comparatively flaccid.
There's just enough blaring sound and color to this knowingly silly tale of interplanetary derring-do to adequately offset its impersonal corporate sheen.
Weaves a number of preceding and subsequent social narratives into its arms-aloft, future-minded celebration.
An essentially simple tale of love across the class divide grows too diffuse and distracted to stir the heart, while its two parallel stories ... never coalesce into a satisfactory mythic dialogue.
Bispuri and co-writer Francesca Manieri don't pass explicit judgment on a custom born out of more problematically ingrained sexism; the script's perspective is more anthropological than political.
No one behaves quite like a human being in Eugene Green's Le Fils de Joseph, yet a soulful sense of humanity emerges from their heightened declamations anyway.
movie_title: The Son of Joseph (Le fils de Joseph) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Fundamentally silly the film may be, but it never graduates to spryness.

In artfully deconstructing a one-night stand with one wistful eye on what was and another on what could have been, Gabe Klinger's first narrative feature winds up feeling appropriately elegiac in a multitude of ways.
The present-day worth of preserved Holocaust death camps is tacitly addressed in Sergei Loznitsa's brilliant observational doc.
A significantly more accomplished and entertaining sequel than 2000's woeful cash-in Book of Shadows: Blair Witch 2, [this] nonetheless reps something of a missed opportunity.
There's no light on the teenage wasteland in Belgian helmer Fien Troch's tough-minded, suitably rough-edged fourth feature.
Spiritual manifestations of grief come out to play in Benoit Jacquot and Julia Roy's slight but slinky adaptation of Don DeLillo's 'The Body Artist.'
Florence Pugh announces herself as a major talent to watch in William Oldroyd's impressively tough-minded Victorian tragedy.
The latest supersized opus from Filipino maximalist Lav Diaz is a powerful and, by his standards, refreshingly contained moral study.
movie_title: The Woman Who Left (Ang babaeng humayo) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Abetted by impressive lo-fi effects work, the musical numbers alone come to resemble the wildest dreams of every Eurovision show producer.
Russian veteran Andrei Konchalovsky is on robust form in this richly monochrome, perspective-rotating Holocaust drama.
A sleek, sorrowful elegy for the prodigiously gifted, tragically slain bop trumpeter Lee Morgan, is as much a visual and textural triumph as it is a gripping feat of reportage.
Efficient, unfussy, and doesn't try to think any faster than it can run.
It's not the best film you'll see this holiday season, but this soft, agreeable adaptation of the man-and-his-cat bestseller has its charms.
"A Hundred Streets" seems oddly unequal to the status of its charismatic name cast, headlined by Idris Elba and Gemma Arterton.

Writer-directors Tomas Weinreb and Petr Kazda construct a still-topical case study of extreme trauma yielded by adolescent bullying and parental neglect, fronted with committed intensity by rising Polish star Michalina Olszanska.
Diverting, mildly informative and - to borrow Caulfield's adjective of choice - somewhat phony, heavy as it is on tortured-writer clichés and contrived art-imitates-life parallels.
A dense, defiantly prickly film about ordinary people who don't really do anything.
One leaves "Marjorie Prime" pleased to have witnessed these actors at work, and rather wishing you'd got to see them tackle this intimate piece in a warmer, flesh-and-blood theatrical context.
This is achingly delicate psychological territory, heavily dependent on just the right actor to make flesh its scripted subtleties - and Hittman has found him in Dickinson ...

Between more trickily opaque stretches of character development, Shortland nails a handful of straight-up, nerve-shredding tension sequences, teasing a version of the film that might have tilted into full-bore horror.
Director Alethea Jones and writer Julie Rudd have some formal finessing to do, but could prove a valuable team in a mainstream comedy landscape still short on loud, proud female voices.

Skipping some of the more predictable narrative obstacles we've come to expect from the coming-out drama, this sexy, thoughtful, hopeful film instead advances a pro-immigration subtext that couldn't be more timely ...
Chilean helmer Pablo Larraín makes an extraordinary English-lingo debut with this daring, many-leveled portrait of history's favorite First Lady.
John Trengove's hard-edged but beautifully wrought study of clashing Xhosa models of masculinity will be an eye-opener to outsiders - and some South Africans too.
The more "Dayveon" attempts to up the dramatic and moral stakes of its narrative, the less persuasive it is as idiosyncratic, indigenous storytelling.
Balancing the perspectives of perpetrators, policemen and victims with wiry tension and tender human interest, it's not entirely the rah-rah flag-waving exercise the title promises.
A moving, stylishly crafted grief memoir that falls a little short on personal detail.
An impassioned advocation of preventative cancer treatment that brazenly counters the methods of Big Pharma.
The title isn't the only "why" question viewers should be asking themselves.
In a film that sporadically attempts to progressively satirize PC workplace culture, the sour smell of misogyny pervades the mulled-wine aroma.
It's the dash of pickle in Robert Siegel's script - a streak of sour, cheek-puckering cynicism amid its warmer, blander conventions - that gives "The Founder" its mojo.
A piercing, immersive, and superbly played convent drama in which the suppression of speech is witnessed at both an individual and institutional level.
Somehow we're never truly surprised by any of its wonders.
A lyrical sense of bittersweet acceptance permeates freshman director Juho Kuosmanen's marvelous sports biopic from its very first, perfectly composed frame.
movie_title: The Happiest Day in the Life of Olli Mäki (Hymyilevä mies) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While shot through with pointed jabs at chauvinism and mainstream homophobia in Mexican society, "The Untamed" never quite exceeds the sum of its intriguingly opposed parts.
High-risk material yields unexpected rewards in this remarkable rape-revenge drama, a possible career high for Paul Verhoeven.
Alessandro Comodin's first narrative feature is a sun-dappled concoction of earthy folklore and artsy esoterica.
movie_title: Happy Times Will Come Soon (I tempi felici verranno presto) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's a film that skilfully makes us feel precisely what we expect to feel from moment to moment, up to and including the long-forestalled waterworks.

Amid all the shifting mirrored surfaces and hazy ambiguities of Olivier Assayas's bewitching, brazenly unconventional ghost story, this much can be said with certainty: Kristen Stewart has become one hell of an actress.
Anurag Kashyap riffs on a grisly episode of Mumbai history in his luridly absorbing serial killer thriller.
The shadow of 'Badlands' falls a little too long over Nathan Morlando's initially promising but fatally derivative teens-on-the-run thriller.
The victims of Uganda's Lord's Resistance Army speak up in novelist Jonathan Littell's lengthy but affecting documentary debut.
It's constantly, engrossingly active, spinning and sparking and exploding in cycles like a Fourth of July catherine wheel.
Like all great humanist filmmaking, Toni Erdmann keeps an eye out for life at the edges, even when the lives in focus consume a whole lot of energy.
Dumont is still in a mordantly merry mood, as this alternately buoyant, bleak and thoroughly bananas seaside ramble makes delightfully clear.
This frostily fascinating film shows life to be a pretty surreal event.
This Monster may not have quite as many facets as its title implies, but Pla's formally deft manipulation of perspective keeps the pic both urgent and even-handed.
movie_title: A Monster With A Thousand Heads (Un Monstruo de Mil Cabezas) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Though there's much to savor in the pic's lavishly distressed visuals and soundscape, its narrative feels increasingly stretched and desultory.
The film has a knowingly conflicted engagement with millennial-generation feminism that freshens its outlook even as it unevenly rejigs many of its predecessor's gags.
"Viva" appealingly makes up for a coy approach with gutsy, grabby follow-through on the high notes.
Lorenzo Vigas' impressive debut charts an unlikely May-December romance with grace, subtlety and tension.
[Offers] a less-than-convincing glimpse into the modern-day pop factory.
A fast, fizzy and frenetically entertaining extension of the manic gaming franchise that, at its zenith, had children of all ages glued to their smartphone screens.
An impressively disciplined, occasionally transporting debut feature from globe-trotting American helmer Brian Perkins.
Jacquot and Helene Zimmer's loose adaptation of the novel acidly critiques the social rigidities of turn-of-the-century Europe, but actually mollifies the acrid irony of Mirbeau's own conclusion.
movie_title: Diary of a Chambermaid (Journal d'une femme de chambre) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Katell Quillévéré's superb third feature is a wrenching medical drama that blends dazzling formal polish with rawest emotion.
Wim Wenders is gone with the windbags in a dully verbose 3D talkfest that says very little of substance.
Swedish helmer Amanda Kernell makes a stirring debut with a coming-of-age tale that pointedly addresses a bygone era of Scandi colonialism.
While not every tonal downshift here is entirely fluid, this remains a smart, risky one-off, unconcerned with those (and there will be many) who can't acquire its taste.

Though it hardly wants for sincerity or ambition, Coixet's portrait of an arduous mid-career expedition by American explorer Josephine Peary is dramatically as pallid and lifeless as the frozen tundra on which it takes place.
By bantering with the lads and slapping their wrists at the same, War Dogs is left with countless rounds of illicit ammo and no clear satirical target.
Taken on [its own] limited terms, "Eight Days a Week" plays nicely enough: the mostly uptempo Side A of a well-stocked greatest hits album, as it were.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Liev Schreiber and Elisabeth Moss add the necessary punch to director Philippe Falardeau's familiar but affecting boxing biopic.
While the film's balmy good vibes are occasionally infectious, the narrowness of its worldview does begin to grate.
It's not great cinema, or even peak "Fabulous," but for a post-Brexit Britain in dire need of some cheering up, it more than does the job.

Though its disquieting premise never quite combusts into a full-scale psychological thriller, Cogitore's accomplished, arresting debut should reverberate widely on the festival circuit; select distributors may proceed with caution.
movie_title: Neither Heaven nor Earth (Ni le ciel ni la terre) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Independence Day: Resurgence" delivers swiftly and generously when it comes to the goods most viewers will have come for - the time-honored joys of blowing stuff up, in set pieces that escalate dizzyingly in size and context.
Corbet should leave this exhaustingly auspicious freshman effort with plenty of notes; one suspects, with some intrigue, that he'll return with far more for us.
Films this exhaustively constructed don't always factor their actors into the design, but here's a gratifying exception.
The film doesn't quite work. The goofball parts just aren't as funny as they're meant to be. But it's enjoyable in stretches, particularly when the zaniness dies down.

Yet it never feels exactly right. This might be a technological matter that, for once, gives the advantage to old-fashioned television - the kind you plug in the wall and watch according to its schedule, not yours.

movie_title: An Adventure in Space and Time (2013)

movie_review_blurb: On the subject of the life and death of Kurt Cobain there is still some work to be done, but Montage of Heck may be as close as we'll get to moving on.

movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

The film is made up of details, and these details create characters who are human beings and not just one dimensional victims.
There are no heroes are villains here, only people who are flawed and desperate. The acting, as in Mungiu's previous films, is extraordinary.

The centerpiece of Kenneth Lonergan's drama Manchester by the Sea is a relatively short scene, a conversation between two characters that contains the most moving moments I've seen on screen in years.

The best thing I can say about this movie is that I hope it inspires people to read, or re-read, the novel.

Maybe a 30-minute television show is the best format to explore the premise. It's a bit thin for a movie that runs 90-plus minutes, though. But the appealing leads do their best with the parts they are given.
movie_title: Up for Love (Un homme à la hauteur) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Koler is a real gem in the lead role.

It isn't as great a movie as All the President's Men, but political junkies won't want to miss it.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: These two-women movies depend on a strong cast and Shelter works because of the talent of the actresses who star in it.

movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Teströl és Lélekröl) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: It tells a twist-filled story about love and loss that will resonate with audiences because of its carefully observed characters and sense of place.

Elementary is a very honest and engrossing story that will bring you back to your school days, and its insights will give you great respect for anyone tough and brave enough to choose teaching as a profession.
There is a feeling of authenticity about the film: Yair knows these kids and teachers, and he never sacrifices the story to make a point.

This delightful and entertaining documentary looks at the life and career of a musical star you thought you knew. It portrays a complex, unique and very talented man who courted controversy his whole life.
movie_title: Sammy Davis, Jr.: I've Gotta Be Me (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In the hands of Kore-eda and his brilliant cast, this isn't a formulaic romantic comedy but an unclassifiable blend of comedy and drama, where you root for the hero even as he lets you down again and again.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A brilliant movie, one that is so rich thematically, visually, musically and emotionally, that one viewing is not enough to begin to absorb all it has to offer.

[Antenna] skillfully blends comedy and drama as the various characters try to live their lives in the increasingly long shadow of their father's obsession, which will strike some as magnificent and others as misguided.
La Vache is beautifully photographed, and both its Algerian and French locations look so lovely that it would be a shame to see the film anywhere other than in a theater.
movie_title: One Man and His Cow (La Vache) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's a combination of Rosemary's Baby, every evil-twin movie you've ever seen, and a chic high-end perfume ad, with an emphasis on the ad.

movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Those who love Shakespeare and great British acting should not pass up The Carer.

Everything in The Sense of Wonder may be just a little too good to be true, but it's intelligent escapism.
movie_title: The Sense Of Wonder (Le Goût des Merveilles) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's a fascinating portrait of a family that finds love after trauma.

Levi, who made Lost Islands, a melodrama that was quite popular here a few years ago, is an accomplished showman and has made an entertaining comedy.

While Klein may have been a fascinating person, this isn't a fascinating film.
While on paper this may not sound like a movie you would enjoy, it is almost inexplicably entertaining while you are watching it.

It's all very well done, with evocative character actors like those used by Fellini, and settings reminiscent of Vittorio De Sica's 1960s comedies.
This isn't a movie meant to inspire much reflection. It aims to entertain and that it does.

movie_title: Under the Hawthorn Tree (Shan zha shu zhi lian) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's an incoherent film, as if Spielberg desperately wanted to say something important and could only come to the conclusion that killing is bad and we're all human.
Although it's set in the 1970s and '80s, it couldn't be more timely.

movie_title: One Week and a Day (Shavua ve Yom) (2017)
